1.1-4.1-1:
Dismissal of a person approaching 2 years of continuous service
You should be aware that the closer the continuous service of the person you wish to terminate approaches 2 years, the more likely he/she would have the opportunity to file a prohibited practice complaint under section 122 of the Act respecting labour standards.
This section prohibits you from acting in such a way as to avoid the application of the law.
This person could claim that your objective in terminating his/her employment is to deprive him/her of rights under the Act respecting labour standards, i.e. to protect him/her from being dismissed without just and sufficient cause. 
In fact, when a person has 2 years of continuous service, he/she has the right to contest his/her dismissal before the Commission des normes, de l'équité, de la santé et de la sécurité du travail if he/she believes that it was done without just and sufficient cause.
Reference: Payette v. Gestion Mimakar inc, D.T.E. 2009T-173 (C.R.T.)
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 122, paragraph 5.
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 124.
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 1, subsection 12.
Reference: https: //www.cnesst.gouv.qc.ca/fr/organisation/documentation/acces-linformation/documents-servant-prise-decision/normes-travail/loi-sur-normes-travail/chapitre-v-recours-art-98-135/section-i1-recours-lencontre-certaines-disparites/article-122
1.1-4.1-2:
Dismissal of a person approaching 2 years of continuous service (continued)
In addition, if that person filed a complaint, he/she would benefit from a presumption that he/she was terminated for a wrongful reason. 
In this case, you would have the burden of rebutting this presumption by showing that you had another just and sufficient cause that was not a pretext for terminating his/her employment.
The closer the person gets to 2 years of continuous service, the more it is recommended that you consult with an attorney to be sure that you have a record to justify the dismissal of this person. 
Reference: Payette v. Gestion Mimakar inc, D.T.E. 2009T-173 (C.R.T.)
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 122, paragraph 5.
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 124.
1.1-4.1-3:
Dismissal for underperformance or incompetence - Employee with more than 2 years
This person has been employed by your company for more than 2 years. 
Therefore, you cannot terminate for performance issues without meeting the following requirements:
1. Have you informed the person in writing of your expectations and the requirements of the company?
2. Have you pointed out in writing what the person deficiencies were?
3. Have you provided the necessary support for the person you consider incompetent to correct the deficiencies and achieve your goals?
4. Have you given the person a reasonable amount of time (often a few months) to adjust?
5. Did you make it clear that the person could be fired if he/she did not improve?
Administrative Labour Tribunal points out that an employer who does not follow this procedure is acting in an abusive and unreasonable manner and the dismissal is cancelled. 
Reference: Laplante v. Costco Wholesale Canada Ltd, D.T.E. 2003T-1058 (C.R.T.).
1.1-4.1-4:
Warning
Since there has been no improvement in competence as a result of the performance improvement plan (PIP) you made with this individual and you have made the decision to terminate the individual, you must ensure that all steps have been followed and that you can demonstrate the efforts you made to enable the incompetent individual to improve.
1.1-4.1-5:
Since the employee has less than 2 years of continuous service, you could terminate the person for poor performance. You can simply indicate that the person does not meet the requirements of the position. You can thus:
M) Maintain employment and improve job performance
O) Terminate employment
CAUTION: IF THE PERSON IS APPROACHING 2 YEARS OF CONTINUOUS SERVICE, THERE ARE ADDITIONAL CHECKS TO BE MADE. 
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, sections 122 and 124.
1.1-4.1-6:
Warning 
Dismissal: a person with a medical condition
It is not recommended to terminate a person's employment because of a medical condition such as a handicap, a disability, chronic disease or substance abuse problems.
If you do so, you might be in violation of the right of the employee to a reasonable accommodation for his/her medical condition or handicap (see Hydro-Québec c. Syndicat des employés-e-s de techniques professionnelles et de bureau d'Hydro-Québec, section locale 2000 (SCFP-FTQ), 2008, CSC 43.)
The person can file a complaint under the Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms if you discriminate against them by terminating  his/her employment for a medical condition.
It is recommended that you retain the services of a lawyer specializing in employment law to assist you in assessing the consequences of dismissing this person.
Reference: Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms, sections 10 and 16.
1.1-4.2-1:
Performance Improvement Plan (PIP)
Based on the information shared today, I recommend that you work jointly with the person on a performance improvement plan (PIP), taking into account the requirements retained by the courts to uphold a dismissal for incompetence.
The purpose of a PIP is to promote awareness and accountability in the person whose performance is unsatisfactory.
It is a means of mediation to correct gaps in the person's observed performance.
1.1-4.2-4:
Change of job position
Before writing a PIP (which takes time and energy), check whether your assessment of his/her competence in the current position is shared by this person. 
You could see with him/her if she is willing to make the effort to improve, being aware that if it doesn't work, you would have to fire him/her. 
See with her if it would not be possible to transfer her to another position for which he/she has the skills and experience.
1.1-4.2-5:
Warning
If there has been no improvement in competency as a result of the PIP and you have made the decision to terminate, you must ensure that all steps have been followed and that you can demonstrate the efforts you have made to allow the incompetent person to improve.
1.1-4.3-1:
Accommodation Obligations
If the person mentions that he/she has a handicap, health or medical problems or substance addiction problems, be a good listener. You should require the person to provide a document signed by a physician attesting to the employee's medical condition.
If the person provides such medical evidence, then you must ensure the reliability of that document and make reasonable accommodations, if necessary. 
You may also want to discuss the situation with the person and see if he/she expresses a desire to move to another position for which he/she has the skills and experience, and which is appropriate for the person's medical condition.
However, it is possible that the accommodation required for this person may be an excessive burden on you, as an employer. It is recommended that you retain the services of an employment lawyer to assist you in the accommodation assessment process.
Reference: see Hydro-Québec c. Syndicat des employés-e-s de techniques professionnelles et de bureau d'Hydro-Québec, section locale 2000 (SCFP-FTQ),2008, CSC 43.
1.1-4.4-1:
Dismissal for Underperformance or Incompetence - Notice Period
In your file, you established a performance improvement plan (PIP) with the person and he/she knew the consequences if he/she did not meet your requirements. Therefore, you have two choices:
Option One
Agree with the person that he/she will continue to work, even if it does not meet the expected quality, for the period of notice provided for in section 82 of the Act respecting labour standards. 
During this period, you must maintain the benefits to which the person is entitled.
The longer the notice period, the less advantageous this choice is for the company.
Warning
This option of remaining employed during the notice period is very risky and counterproductive. It is far preferable to terminate the employment and pay the notice period compensation as a person who is terminated for incompetence will not be competent to work during the notice period and will likely not be engaged or productive. 
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 82.
1.1-4.4-2:
Dismissal for Underperformance or Incompetence - Notice Period (continued)
Option Two
Decide that the statutory notice period will not be worked, but paid in the form of compensation.
This is calculated on the individual's regular salary during the notice period.
Overtime is not included in the calculation of the indemnity.
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, section 82.
1.1-4.4-3:
The Act respecting labour standards provides that the employer must give notice to any person who works for him/her and whose employment is terminated, unless that person has committed a serious fault. It should be noted that a fault that merits dismissal is not necessarily a serious fault within the meaning of the Act. 
The notice period is calculated based on the length of continuous service (calculated from the date of hire or rehire) of the person with the company:
less than three months - NO NOTICE
three months to less than one year - ONE WEEK NOTICE
one year to less than five years - TWO WEEKS NOTICE
five years to less than ten years - FOUR WEEKS NOTICE
ten years and over - EIGHT WEEKS NOTICE
If you do not want to give working notice, you must give the equivalent of the notice in money. This compensation must be equal to the regular salary that person would have earned during the period of notice. Overtime must not be included in the calculation of the compensation. You must also pay him/her the amounts due (e.g., salary, overtime, vacation).
The annual vacation period is not included in the notice period and the person's benefits must be maintained during the notice period.
Reference: Act respecting labour standards, sections 82 and 82.1.
1.1-4.4-4:
Dismissal for Underperformance or Incompetence - Individual's Civil Remedy
Even if you give the notice or compensation provided for in the Act respecting labour standards, a person who feels that he/she should have more generous compensation because of certain criteria may still be able to file a recourse in the Quebec civil courts under section 2091 of the Civil Code of Quebec.
If you decide to offer more than what is provided for in the Act respecting labour standards, it is suggested that you have the dismissed employee sign a waiver of his/her right to sue before the courts. 
However, the person is under no obligation to sign such a waiver.
Reference: Civil Code of Quebec, section 2091.
1.1-4.4-5:
Best Practices for Termination of Employment 
You have made the decision to terminate that persons employment. How you will deal with this person is important to that person as well as to the employees who remain in your employ. Your actions have much more impact than your words fort the mobilization of your team. If you say you respect your employees, you must show it.
Here are the steps you need to follow:
1.1-4.4-6:
1. Prepare the termination letter with the reasons for the termination of employment. In this letter, you will have specified the severance pay for this person. This indemnity can never be less than the minimum provided for in the Act respecting Labour Standards. Depending on the position held by this person, the length of his/her continuous service and his/her employment contract, if he/she has one, it is recommended to consult a lawyer or a Human Resources specialist.
Arrange a meeting in person (or virtually if it is not possible to do so in person). Do not inform the employee by phone, email, or text message. Schedule the meeting around lunchtime or at the end of the workday when there is less activity at work.
1.1-4.4-7:
2. At the meeting, review the facts that led to this decision. The purpose of the meeting is not to allow the person to question the merits of your decision, but to inform him/her that it is over and to talk about the terms of the departure.
Depending on the case, you may decide to be accompanied for this meeting, but you should not ask a colleague of this person. It is suggested that someone related to Human Resources or another manager be present.
1.1-4.4-8: 3. Allow the person who has been terminated to leave with dignity. Unless the termination is for theft or fraud, there is no reason to have the person escorted to the door by a security guard.
1.1-4.4-9:
If the terminated person has a lot of personal belongings in his/her office, you may suggest that he/she comes back outside of working hours to pick them up. Depending on the nature of the position, it is possible that there is a transmission of files to be done. Establish with him/her how this will be done. 
If you are confident that the person will not cause damage, you can let him/her go to his/her office alone to collect his/her belongings and greet his/her colleagues. He/she can also choose to leave discreetly. Agree together on the message that will be conveyed to the colleagues and to the organization. 
Make sure the person is able to return home safely. Each person reacts differently. Although you may have terminated their employment for good reasons, it affects his/her work life and his/her personal life.
